Award.AwardTitle: CCF: SHF: Small: Collaborative Research: Domain-specific Reconfigurable Processor for Time-Series Data Mining and Monitoring

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal will investigate techniques to improve performance and reduce the cost and energy consumption of wearable devices (e.g., Internet-of-Things) that perform real-time medical monitoring. The objective is to demonstrate how to construct programmable integrated circuits that can provide monitoring capabilities while remaining small enough to be convenient and unobtrusive to the wearer. As a motivating example, such a device could detect and predict medical problems of fundamental importance such as pericardial tamponade, a life-threatening emergency where in the pericardium (a sac surrounding the heart) fills with fluid and prevents the heart from pumping blood, leading quickly and directly to death. Broader impacts of this effort include: reducing the cost of medical monitoring and saving lives; introduction of undergraduate students at both institutions to hardware/software co-design for wearable computing through a Freshman Discovery Seminar; inclusion of women and underrepresented minorities in the project; public release of hardware and software developed in the course of this project; and tutorial dissemination targeting the database/data mining and design automation research communities.


The technical approach will involve the creation of application-specific integrated circuit hardware that can be added to embedded processors and microcontrollers to improve the performance of real-time medical monitoring applications. The research is based on the observation that real world data sets often exhibit a significant disparity in the dimensionality (data sampling rate) and cardinality (number of distinct values) of the data; for example, echocardiograms (ECGs) are often sampled at 1,024 Hz and 64-bits, although reducing the dimensionality to 128 Hz and the cardinality to 8-bits suffice for real-time monitoring. The fundamental challenge is that the minimum dimensionality and cardinality may vary from task-to-task, from individual-to-individual, and possibly even from hour-to-hour for a given individual. The Minimum Description Length (MDL) principle will be investigated as a potential solution to find the intrinsic dimensionality and cardinality of the data source, which can reduce data volume and improve detection accuracy by noise reduction. This information will then be leveraged to design domain-specific adaptive architectures that can exploit this reduced data volume to improve throughput and enhance battery lifetime.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to perform data mining on hardware, techniques exploiting low dimensionality and low cardinality of data should be developed. Fundamental challenge in the process is in finding ways to represent the data succinctly to enable mining algorithms on hardware. Furthermore, we find that data representation largely depends on the types and properties of data such as sparsity, amount of annotation and signal-to-noise ratio.

 

This project developed data mining algorithms for time series data exploiting low cardinality and low dimensionality of data. The methods exploit various data representations such as run-length encoding, Singular Spectrum Analysis (SSA) and Nearest Neighbor Graph (NNG) to extract meaningful patterns from sparse, noisy and partially labeled data with greater efficiency and accuracy. The project also developed streaming pattern matching algorithm suitable for medical and seismic monitoring applications. The algorithm is amenable to distributed computation with hardware accelerated compute units.

 

The project demonstrated data mining applications in three domains: neuroimaging, seismology and social science. The project supported development of an online repository of patient data and computational tools for EEG data (http://predict.cs.unm.edu/). Semi-supervised algorithmdeveloped in this project can successfully find uncataloged earthquakes in seismic data. Sparse data mining techniques developed in this project can spot automation in social communication.

 

The project produced two Ph.D.'s (Hossein Hamooni and Nikan Chavoshi) and supported four students in their graduate research. The project supported two undergraduate students (Kevin Omidvaran and Jennifer Longo) as REU participants. Kevin is currently attending graduate school at UCI, and Jennifer is strongly motivated to graduate studies. PI produced two tutorials based on the research performed in this project, and presented in KDD 2017, SDM 2019 and CIKM 2019. All code, data and presentation slides are available online for downloading at PI's website.

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2019
Modified by: Abdullah Mueen
